final_answer.precision_note: Derived from titrant moles and stoichiometric 1:2 ratio, rounded to 3 significant figures.

method: Calculate moles of NaOH added. V(NaOH)=23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3, so n(NaOH)=cV=0.150	imes0.02340=3.51	imes10^-3 mol. Use the reaction H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O from the line of data: one mole H2SO4 consumes two moles NaOH. Therefore n(H2SO4)=n(NaOH)/2 = 1.755	imes10^-3 mol. Divide by sample volume 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3 to get c(H2SO4)=1.755	imes10^-3/0.02500=7.02	imes10^-2 mol dm-3.
checks: Stoichiometric factor is exactly 2, so acid moles are half the moles of NaOH.
Concentration is moles of H2SO4 divided by 0.02500 dm3, giving 0.0702 mol dm-3.
The units from mol dm-3 are consistent with c=n/V where V is in dm3.
